I've almost finished this book. It is very very easy reading and it contains
only necessary information. I even found this one easier to read than the first
two books of the serie.

> How generic is the book?  Is it somewhat (or greatly) applicable to
> projects outside of Java?

In the "building" part, I presume, if you're using .NET, you can replace
CruiseControl with CruiseControl.NET and Ant with NAnt, JUnit with NUnit, etc.
Source code control system is CVS so if you're using something like VSS you
won't be able to take advantage of the same branching, merging concepts.

Deployment talks about JAR, WAR files, which are specific to Java (even though
one can see them as a pure packaging mechanism).

I haven't started the monitoring part yet, but I assume it's going to talk
about JMX, etc.

Even though the concepts should be applicable to different programming
environments, the book uses Java related tools, as the name goes "How to build,
deploy and monitor Java apps". I, personally, wouldn't enjoy reading about
another technology and trying to apply the concepts, filling the gaps, etc.

Hope this helps,

 - Yagiz Erkan -
 http://yagiz.blogspot.com
